item.title: Foxconn Pulls Chinese Staff From India in Hurdle for Apple
item.description: Foxconn Technology Group has asked hundreds of Chinese engineers and technicians to return home from its iPhone factories in India, dealing a blow to Apple Inc.’s manufacturing push in the South Asian country.

item.title: Robotics Startup Raises $105 Million Seed From US, China VCs
item.description: Genesis AI, a startup working on software for robots, has raised $105 million in a funding round with both US and Chinese backers — a rarity in an industry split along geopolitical lines.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Berthelot

item.title: Amazon Hiring Executives for Asia Satellite Internet Push
item.description: Amazon.com Inc. is looking to hire government sales leads in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, laying the groundwork for its satellite internet business in East Asia.

item.title: Polish Studio Behind ‘Silent Hill’ Remake Plans Original Games
item.description: Few expected a small Polish studio like Bloober Team SA to do justice to Silent Hill 2 with their remake of the survival horror classic. Yet the game turned out to be one of last year’s biggest hits, selling two million copies in just four months while winning award nominations and critical acclaim.
item.dc:creator: Mark Anderson, Zheping Huang

media:content.media:description: In Cronos: The New Dawn, monsters can merge with one another even after they’re slayed.

item.title: Chinese Investors Dump Tencent, Xiaomi Shares as Rally Fizzles
item.description: Chinese investors ditched some of the biggest tech stocks in Hong Kong last month, testing the resilience of their market-beating rally this year.
item.dc:creator: Jeanny Yu

item.title: Alibaba Offers $7 Billion of Subsidies to Defend Turf in China
item.description: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd is offering 50 billion yuan ($7 billion) of subsidies for food deliveries and online retail to boost its instant commerce business in China as competition heats up.
item.dc:creator: Debby Wu

item.title: Cybersecurity Flaws Plagued EU Border Control System, Audit Shows
item.description: An information-sharing system used by EU border forces to flag illegal immigrants and suspected criminals in real time was rife with software and security vulnerabilities, according to emails and confidential audit reports obtained by Bloomberg News and investigative newsroom Lighthouse Reports.

item.title: Columbia University Applicants’ Personal Data Stolen by Hacker
item.description: Personal information about Columbia University students and applicants — including whether they were accepted or rejected by the school — has been stolen, according to a Bloomberg News review of data provided by a person who claimed to have hacked the school in June.

item.title: Hyundai Sharpens User Experience Focus With New Research Lab
item.description: Hyundai Motor Co. is deepening its push into understanding how drivers experience vehicles with the launch of a new showroom and research lab in Seoul, part of a broader effort to embed next-generation software into its cars.

item.title: Google Ends Recipe Pilot That Left Creators Fearing Web-Traffic Hit
item.description: Google has ended tests of a feature that would have let users open a snapshot of cooking-recipe content directly in web search results — a welcome development for creators and food bloggers who were concerned about eroding traffic to their sites.
item.dc:creator: Julia Love, Davey Alba

media:content.media:description: The Google Chrome search page on a smartphone arranged in the Queens borough of New York, US, on Tuesday, Nov. 19, 2024. Top Justice Department antitrust officials have decided to ask a judge to force Alphabet Inc.'s Google to sell off its Chrome browser in what would be a historic crackdown on one of the biggest tech companies in the world.

item.title: Google Owes $314 Million for Misusing Android Cell Phone Data
item.description: Google was told by a California jury to pay $314 million over claims that it illegally used Android users’ cellular data to collect information without their knowledge.
item.dc:creator: Anika Arora Seth

item.title: Donald Trump, Elon Musk Fallout Deepens | Bloomberg Tech 7/1/2025
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss the clashes between President Donald Trump and Elon Musk. Plus, the Tesla CEO will oversee sales in Europe and the US as investors brace for disappointing delivery numbers in the second quarter. And, Apple considers using outside AI from Anthropic or OpenAI to power Siri. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Huawei Bid to Dismiss US Trade Sanction Case Rejected by Judge
item.description: Huawei Technologies Co. must face a criminal trial next year in New York after a federal judge refused a request by the Chinese wireless equipment maker to dismiss more than a dozen charges, including racketeering, trade secret theft and violating US sanctions on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Hurtado

item.title: Chipmakers Win Bigger Tax Credit Under Bill Passed by Senate
item.description: Sweeping tax legislation passed by the Senate Tuesday would make it cheaper for semiconductor manufacturers to build plants in the US, delivering a win to chipmakers and boosting US efforts to expand the industry domestically.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz, Mackenzie Hawkins

item.title: X Will Deploy AI to Write Community Notes, Expand Fact-Checking
item.description: Elon Musk’s X will start to publish Community Notes written by artificial intelligence agents, a move to increase the speed of the social network’s fact-checking product and expand it to reach more people.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Wagner

item.title: E-Commerce Firm Jumia Draws Takeover Interest From Axian
item.description: Jumia Technologies AG, the biggest e-commerce company in Africa, has drawn takeover interest from telecommunications company Axian Telecom, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Loni Prinsloo

media:content.media:description: A worker scans inventory inside a Jumia Technologies AG distribution warehouse in Lagos, Nigeria, on Friday, April 12, 2019. Jumia shares soared by 75 percent on their first day of trading in New York, as investors rushed to buy into the companys plans to extend online shopping services across Africa.
